Single-Stranded Probe Excess Titration of Specific Embryonic Transcripts
Introduction (Tissue-specific 
The genome of S. purpuratus contains eight different actin genes. Each of the
active genes (six known) of this family is regulated independently during development and
functions in diverse cell lineages or sets of cell lineages at diverse stages of
development. Transcripts of one gene, called M, are confined to muscle cells in adult sea
urchins, and in the embryo to muscle anlage cells that differentiate after gastrulation.
The remaining five active actin genes are all expressed in non-muscle cell types, and
presumably code for cytoskeletal actin proteins. One of these, is exclusively
expressed in the aboral ectoderm of plutei and in presumptive aboral ectoderm at
blastula stage. Thus, the transcript is a specific molecular marker for the aboral
ectoderm cell lineage.
The endoskeletal spicules of the sea urchin embryo are elaborated by the primary
cells, descendants of the micromeres, beginning at gastrulation, and
increase in size and complexity as the pluteus larva matures. The mineral component of
the skeletal structures is a 20:1 complex that is deposited within a
protein template secreted by the skeletogenic cells. The major component
of the spicule matrix is a glycoprotein called SM50. The SM50 gene is expressed
exclusively in the skeletogenic its transcripts appearing in primary
cells even before the onset of skeletogenesis. The SM50 gene, then, is a
molecular marker for the skeletogenic cells.
The numbers of and SM50 transcript molecules that are accumulated in S.
purpuratus embryos have been determined. In the 64-hr pluteus (~l800 cells) there are
about CylIIa molecules present, or 190 transcripts per aboral ectoderm
cell (~l+70 cells total). The prevalence of SM50 is about 130 molecules per
primary cell (~60 cells total) in the 3-day pluteus. These measurements
were made using a single-stranded probe excess titration technique described by Lee
et al. (1986). ln this method total embryo RNA is mixed at 5/Qrious mass ratios with an
excess amount (with respect to the sequence of interest) of P-labeled single-stranded
probe (RNA in the experiments above), and reacted in solution to completion. The
amount of nuclease-resistant hybrids that form with the various amounts of
total embryo RNA is then measured. From these determinations the prevalence of the
in question may be calculated as follows:
Mass of xy/B6 where
(cpm for 32P)/ug RNA slope of titration curve
total RNA/embryo 2.8 ng
3 probe specific activity (cpm)/ug probe
5 fraction of contained in probe probe length/mRNA length
.0028 ug RNA
mass probe length embryo
ug probe length
The mass/embryo may then, of course, be converted to numbers of
transcripts/embryo (or cell), based on the known molecular weight (ug/transcript) of the
